iceAgesAndEarlyEgypt.name: Nabla Playa
iceAgesAndEarlyEgypt.note: Sahara Desert Transformation (Green Sahara to Desert)
iceAgesAndEarlyEgypt.description: The Sahara was once a lush, green savanna with lakes and rivers before desertification set in around 6000–5000 years ago. Ancient megalithic site in the Sahara.

iceAgesAndEarlyEgypt.name: Wadi Howar
iceAgesAndEarlyEgypt.note: Extinct river in Sudan, once connected to the Nile.

iceAgesAndEarlyEgypt.name: Air Mountains
iceAgesAndEarlyEgypt.note: Last refuge of Sahara’s green past.

iceAgesAndEarlyEgypt.name: Sinai Peninsula
iceAgesAndEarlyEgypt.note: The Ice Age & Early Human Migrations.
iceAgesAndEarlyEgypt.description: Humans migrated across frozen and exposed landmasses, shaping ancient civilizations.

iceAgesAndEarlyEgypt.name: Southern route to India via Arabian Coast
iceAgesAndEarlyEgypt.note: Humans migrated across frozen and exposed landmasses.

iceAgesAndEarlyEgypt.name: Crossings into the Americas via Beringia
iceAgesAndEarlyEgypt.note: Humans migrated across frozen and exposed landmasses.

seaLevelChangesAndIceAges.name: Ice Age Sea Level Changes & Submerged Lands
seaLevelChangesAndIceAges.note: During the Last Glacial Maximum (~20,000 years ago), sea level changes submerged lands and exposed vast landmasses.

pyramids.name: Bent Pyramid
pyramids.note: Also known as The Black Pyramid

statuesAndObelisks.name: Cleopatra's Needles
statuesAndObelisks.note: Originally in Heliopolis. Moved to London & NYC

tombs.name: KV1 (Ramesses VII)
tombs.description: Features scenes from the Book of the Dead but has suffered damage over time.

tombs.name: KV2 (Ramesses II)
tombs.description: A large tomb with intricate decorations depicting the pharaoh's journey in the afterlife.

tombs.name: KV3 (Merneptah)
tombs.description: Notable for its depictions of religious rituals and military achievements.

tombs.name: KV5 (Sons of Ramesses II)
tombs.description: One of the largest tombs, with over 100 chambers.

tombs.name: KV6 (Ramesses IX)
tombs.description: Contains well-preserved murals showcasing burial rituals.

tombs.name: KV7 (Ramesses IV)
tombs.description: Features extensive decorations from the Book of the Gates and a large sarcophagus.

tombs.name: Valley of the Queens
tombs.note: Over 70 tombs found in this valley.

tombs.name: QV51
tombs.description: Queen Isis, wife of Ramses III and mother of Ramses VI, her tomb features inscriptions of her presenting offerings to gods. Unfortunately, it is in poor condition.

tombs.name: QV52
tombs.description: Queen Titi. Although damaged, it contains detailed inscriptions and depictions of Queen Titi worshipping Egyptian gods such as Ptah and Ra-Horakhty.

tombs.name: QV55
tombs.description: Belonged to Amun-her-khepeshef, the eldest son of Ramesses III.

tombs.name: QV88
tombs.description: Prince Ahmose. A lesser-known tomb belonging to a prince from the 18th Dynasty.

tombs.name: QV66
tombs.description: Belonging to Queen Nefertari, the Great Wife of Pharaoh Ramesses II. Her tomb is often referred to as the 'Sistine Chapel of Ancient Egypt' due to its stunning and well-preserved wall paintings.

tombs.name: QV42
tombs.description: Prince Parherwenemef. A son of Ramses III, though his tomb is not well preserved.

tombs.name: Other notable tombs
tombs.description: Queen Henuttauy, Prince Menjeperre (son of Thutmose III), Princess Meritamon, Prince Ramses.

tombs.name: Saqqara Necropolis
tombs.note: Tomb of Hotepsekhemwy, the founder of the Second Dynasty of Egypt.

temples.name: Abu Simbel
temples.description: Temples of Ramesses II, relocated due to the Aswan Dam.

temples.name: Kouklia
temples.description: Palaepaphos - Worship of Aphrodite with Egyptian Influence.
temples.note: Aphrodite’s temple here may have had connections to Egyptian fertility goddesses (Hathor, Isis). Egyptian artifacts and Bronze Age trade links found in the region.

temples.name: Temple of Horus at Edfu
temples.note: Built under Ptolemaic rule, this temple blended Greek and Egyptian architectural styles while honoring Egyptian deities.

temples.name: Kom Ombo
temples.note: A unique double temple built during the Ptolemaic period, dedicated to both the crocodile god Sobek and the falcon god Haroeris.

temples.name: Rome
temples.note: After the conquest of Egypt in 30 BCE, Rome absorbed its wealth, culture, and even obelisks, placing them in public spaces. The Temple of Isis in Rome became a major religious center.

temples.name: Seis
temples.note: Plato wrote that Egyptian priests in Sais told Solon the story of Atlantis.

villages.name: Deir el-Medina
villages.description: Village for artisans who built royal tombs.

villages.name: Kahun
villages.description: Pyramid Builder's Town. Middle Kingdom worker's town.

harbours_ports.name: Thoris-Heracleion & Canopus
harbours_ports.description: Sunken Ports of the Nile Delta

harbours_ports.name: Perunefer
harbours_ports.description: Memphis Royal Harbour. Launched Egypt's navy.

harbours_ports.name: Abu Sha'ar
harbours_ports.description: Ptolemaic-Roman Naval Base. Launched Egypt's navy.

harbours_ports.name: Wadi al-Jarf
harbours_ports.description: Oldest known harbor. Khufu's era c. 2600 BCE

harbours_ports.name: Ayn Sokhna
harbours_ports.description: Old Kingdom Copper Trade Port. Handled copper, incense, and exotic goods from the Sinai and Punt.

harbours_ports.name: Myos Hormos
harbours_ports.description: Main Roman Red Sea port. Egyptian ports used by the Romans for trade with India, Arabia, and East Africa.

harbours_ports.name: Rhodes
harbours_ports.description: The Ptolemaic Naval Base. A key ally of Ptolemaic Egypt, Rhodes housed Egyptian-funded projects and was crucial in Mediterranean trade.

fortresses_military_strongholds.name: Buhen
fortresses_military_strongholds.description: Nubian Fortress. Old Kingdom defense on the Nile. Sunken.

fortresses_military_strongholds.name: Pelusium
fortresses_military_strongholds.description: A key Roman defensive position on Egypt’s eastern border, guarding against invasions from the Levant.

trading_routes_hubs.name: Suakin, Sudan
trading_routes_hubs.description: Possible northern edge of Punt based on ancient trade routes.

trading_routes_hubs.name: Dahlak Archipelago, Eritrea
trading_routes_hubs.description: Fits descriptions of Punt's coastal harbors and myrrh trees.

trading_routes_hubs.name: Berbera, Somalia
trading_routes_hubs.description: Considered by some scholars as a Punt trading center.

trading_routes_hubs.name: Ras Hafun, Somalia
trading_routes_hubs.description: A prehistoric trade site where Egyptians may have obtained gold, incense, and exotic animals.

trading_routes_hubs.name: Al-Ula & Dedan
trading_routes_hubs.description: Ancient city along the incense and spice trade. Lihyanite & Dedanite Kingdoms.

trading_routes_hubs.name: Elephantine
trading_routes_hubs.description: Southern trade & military outpost, near Aswan.

trading_routes_hubs.name: Pyla-Kokkinokremos
trading_routes_hubs.description: Abandoned city with Egyptian-Mycenaean artifacts. Short-lived fortified settlement (c. 1200 BCE), abandoned suddenly. Egyptian and Mycenaean pottery found here, suggesting a multicultural trading hub.

trading_routes_hubs.name: Berenice Troglodytica
trading_routes_hubs.description: Trade route to India. Egyptian ports used by the Romans for trade with India, Arabia, and East Africa.

trading_routes_hubs.name: Alexandria
trading_routes_hubs.description: Capital of Roman Egypt. The Hellenistic Capital. Ptolemaic Capital & Trade Hub.

trading_routes_hubs.name: Naukratis
trading_routes_hubs.description: The first Greek colony in Egypt. A Greek trading post established in the 7th century BCE, serving as a cultural and commercial bridge between Greece and Egypt.

trading_routes_hubs.name: Delos
trading_routes_hubs.description: The Island of Egyptian Gods. A major religious and trade hub, Delos had temples dedicated to Isis and Serapis, showing Egypt’s influence in the Aegean.

stops.name: Najran
stops.description: One of the key stops on the Arabian incense trade route.

stops.name: Dedan
stops.description: Major stop in Saudi Arabia, modern Al-Ula.

stops.name: Gaza
stops.description: The Philistines (Peleset) settled in the Pentapolis.

stops.name: Tjaru
stops.description: Also part of The Way of Horus.

stops.name: Gaza
stops.description: The Philistines (Peleset) settled in the Pentapolis.

routes.route_name: The Forty Days Road route (Egypt to Sudan)

stops.name: The Darb el-Arbain
stops.description: A major north-south desert trade route connecting Upper Egypt to Nubia and Sudan. It was famous for caravans transporting gold, incense, ivory, and slaves.

stops.name: Kerma
stops.description: Major Nubian Kingdom, end of route.

stops.name: Wadi al-Jarf
stops.description: Oldest known Egyptian harbor, Red Sea.

stops.name: Quseir al-Qadim
stops.description: Possible Roman continuation of this route.

stops.name: Aden, Yemen
stops.description: Arabian trade hub for incense & myrrh.

stops.name: Punt
stops.description: Likely near modern Eritrea or Somalia.

miscellaneous_religious_sites.name: Qurayyah
miscellaneous_religious_sites.description: Rock inscriptions show Egyptian-style motifs from the New Kingdom (c. 1400s BCE).

miscellaneous_religious_sites.name: Abydos
miscellaneous_religious_sites.description: Major religious site, early kings’ burial place.

miscellaneous_religious_sites.name: Philae
miscellaneous_religious_sites.description: Last Bastion of Egyptian Religion. The Temple of Isis at Philae was among the last active centers of traditional Egyptian religion, even under Roman rule.

oasis_locations.name: Siwa Oasis
oasis_locations.description: Famous for the Oracle of Amun (consulted by Alexander the Great).

oasis_locations.name: Bahariya Oasis
oasis_locations.description: Gold & mineral-rich area, linked to Egyptian mining expeditions.

oasis_locations.name: Dakhla Oasis
oasis_locations.description: Agricultural & caravan stop in the Western Desert.

cyprus.name: Enkomi
cyprus.description: Possible capital of Alashiya. Kingdom of Alashiya, was a state which existed in the Middle and Late Bronze Ages, and was situated somewhere in the Eastern Mediterranean. Mentioned in Egyptian, Ugaritic, and Hittite texts as a key trade partner.

cyprus.name: Kition
cyprus.description: Egyptian Trade & Religious Center in Cyprus. Egyptian artifacts, Hathor temple, and sphinx statues were found here.

cyprus.name: Hala Sultan Tekke
cyprus.description: Archaeological Site with Egyptian Trade Goods. Major Late Bronze Age settlement (1600–1100 BCE).

cyprus.name: Maa-Palaeokastro
cyprus.description: Fortified City from the Bronze Age Collapse, Possible Egyptian Interaction with Sea Peoples. This site was fortified after 1200 BCE, around the time of the Sea Peoples' raids on Egypt. Could have been a Sea Peoples' settlement or a refuge from their attacks.

cyprus.name: Kouklia
cyprus.description: Palaepaphos - Worship of Aphrodite with Egyptian Influence. Aphrodite’s temple here may have had connections to Egyptian fertility goddesses (Hathor, Isis). Egyptian artifacts and Bronze Age trade links found in the region.

cyprus.name: Pyla-Kokkinokremos
cyprus.description: Abandoned City with Egyptian-Mycenaean Artifacts. Short-lived fortified settlement (c. 1200 BCE), abandoned suddenly. Egyptian and Mycenaean pottery found here, suggesting a multicultural trading hub.

syria.name: Ugarit
syria.description: Destroyed during the Sea Peoples' Invasions, Egypt mentioned in its Archives.

lebanon.name: Byblos
lebanon.description: Lebanese Port, Traded with Both Egypt & Cyprus.

sea_peoples.name: Canaan
sea_peoples.description: A likely landing area for the Sea Peoples. Egypt controlled cities here before losing them.

sea_peoples.name: Battle of the Nile Delta
sea_peoples.description: Ramesses III’s Victory, c. 1175 BCE. Ramesses III defeated the Sea Peoples in a naval battle, preventing invasion.

sea_peoples.name: Ashkelon
sea_peoples.description: The Philistines (Peleset) settled in the Pentapolis.

sea_peoples.name: Ashdod
sea_peoples.description: The Philistines (Peleset) settled in the Pentapolis.

sea_peoples.name: Ekron (Tel Miqne)
sea_peoples.description: The Philistines (Peleset) settled in the Pentapolis.

sea_peoples.name: Gath (Tel es-Safi)
sea_peoples.description: The Philistines (Peleset) settled in the Pentapolis.

sea_peoples.name: Miletus
sea_peoples.description: Lukka Influence. Possible Sea Peoples' Origins.

sea_peoples.name: Sardinia
sea_peoples.description: Sherden homeland? Possible Sea Peoples' Origins.

sea_peoples.name: Crete
sea_peoples.description: Denyen & Ekwesh possible ties to Minoans/Mycanaeans.

sea_peoples.name: Walls of the Ruler
sea_peoples.description: Defended Egypt’s eastern border against Canaanite & Sea Peoples' invasions.

sea_peoples.name: Timna Valley
sea_peoples.description: Possible Egyptian Copper Mines in Canaan. Evidence of Egyptian New Kingdom control of copper mining.

sea_peoples.name: Maa-Palaeokastro
sea_peoples.description: Fortified City from the Bronze Age Collapse, Possible Egyptian Interaction with Sea Peoples. This site was fortified after 1200 BCE, around the time of the Sea Peoples' raids on Egypt. Could have been a Sea Peoples' settlement or a refuge from their attacks.

sea_peoples.name: Ugarit
sea_peoples.description: Destroyed during the Sea Peoples' Invasions, Egypt mentioned in its Archives.

sea_peoples.name: Siege of Gaza (332 BCE)
sea_peoples.description: Final Persian Resistance. Before entering Egypt, Alexander besieged Gaza, which resisted for two months before falling.

roman_empire.name: Thebes (Luxor)
roman_empire.description: New Kingdom capital, religious center. Founded by Emperor Hadrian in honor of his companion Antinous. A Romanized Egyptian city.

roman_empire.name: Pelusium
roman_empire.description: A key Roman defensive position on Egypt’s eastern border, guarding against invasions from the Levant.

roman_empire.name: Philae
roman_empire.description: Last Bastion of Egyptian Religion. The Temple of Isis at Philae was among the last active centers of traditional Egyptian religion, even under Roman rule.

roman_empire.name: Mons Claudianus
roman_empire.description: Another location for Roman Stone Quarries.

roman_empire.name: Myos Hormos
roman_empire.description: Main Roman Red Sea port. Egyptian ports used by the Romans for trade with India, Arabia, and East Africa.

roman_empire.name: Berenice Troglodytica
roman_empire.description: Trade route to India. Egyptian ports used by the Romans for trade with India, Arabia, and East Africa.

roman_empire.name: Siege of Gaza (332 BCE)
roman_empire.description: Final Persian Resistance. Before entering Egypt, Alexander besieged Gaza, which resisted for two months before falling.

roman_empire.name: Siwa Oasis
roman_empire.description: Visit to the Oracle of Amun at Siwa Oasis (331 BCE). Alexander the Great traveled through the desert to consult the Oracle of Amun, who allegedly declared him a divine son of Zeus-Ammon.

roman_empire.name: Alexandria
roman_empire.description: Capital of Roman Egypt. The Hellenistic Capital. Egypt’s administrative and cultural center under Roman rule, home to the famous Library and Lighthouse. Founded by Alexander the Great, Alexandria became the cultural and economic center of Hellenistic Egypt.

roman_empire.name: The Great Library of Alexandria
roman_empire.description: One of the most significant intellectual centers of the ancient world, attracting scholars from across the Mediterranean.

roman_empire.name: Pharos Lighthouse
roman_empire.description: One of the Seven Wonders. A massive lighthouse built on the island of Pharos, guiding ships into Alexandria’s harbor.

roman_empire.name: Canopus
roman_empire.description: Greek Hellenistic & Religious Influence. A hub of Greek settlement and the cult of Serapis, a deity combining Greek and Egyptian religious elements.

roman_empire.name: Memphis
roman_empire.description: Religious & Administrative Center. While Alexandria became the capital, Memphis remained an important religious and administrative center under Greek rule.

roman_empire.name: Rome
roman_empire.description: The Egyptian Obelisks & Temples. After the conquest of Egypt in 30 BCE, Rome absorbed its wealth, culture, and even obelisks, placing them in public spaces.

roman_empire.name: Naples
roman_empire.description: The Egyptian Cult in Southern Italy.

greek_influence.name: Pharos Lighthouse
greek_influence.description: One of the Seven Wonders. A massive lighthouse built on the island of Pharos, guiding ships into Alexandria’s harbor.

greek_influence.name: Canopus
greek_influence.description: Greek Hellenistic & Religious Influence. A hub of Greek settlement and the cult of Serapis, a deity combining Greek and Egyptian religious elements.

greek_influence.name: Memphis
greek_influence.description: Religious & Administrative Center. While Alexandria became the capital, Memphis remained an important religious and administrative center under Greek rule.

greek_influence.name: Naukratis
greek_influence.description: The First Greek Colony in Egypt. A Greek trading post established in the 7th century BCE, serving as a cultural and commercial bridge between Greece and Egypt.

greek_influence.name: Temple of Horus at Edfu
greek_influence.description: Greek-Egyptian Architecture. Built under Ptolemaic rule, this temple blended Greek and Egyptian architectural styles while honoring Egyptian deities.

greek_influence.name: Kom Ombo
greek_influence.description: Temple of Sobek & Haroeris. A unique double temple built during the Ptolemaic period, dedicated to both the crocodile god Sobek and the falcon god Haroeris.

greek_influence.name: Athens
greek_influence.description: Egyptian Influence in Classical Greece. Egyptian religion and knowledge influenced Greek thought, with temples to Isis and Serapis appearing in Athens.

greek_influence.name: Delos
greek_influence.description: The Island of Egyptian Gods. A major religious and trade hub, Delos had temples dedicated to Isis and Serapis, showing Egypt’s influence in the Aegean.

greek_influence.name: Rhodes
greek_influence.description: The Ptolemaic Naval Base. A key ally of Ptolemaic Egypt, Rhodes housed Egyptian-funded projects and was crucial in Mediterranean trade.

greek_influence.name: Pergamon
greek_influence.description: Intellectual Rival to Alexandria. The Library of Pergamon was a rival to Alexandria’s Great Library, leading to competition in scholarship and manuscript production.

greek_influence.name: Rome
greek_influence.description: The Egyptian Obelisks & Temples. After the conquest of Egypt in 30 BCE, Rome absorbed its wealth, culture, and even obelisks, placing them in public spaces.

greek_influence.name: Naples
greek_influence.description: The Egyptian Cult in Southern Italy. Naples had a strong cult of Isis, with Egyptian-style temples and iconography influencing Roman religious practices.

greek_influence.name: Cumae
greek_influence.description: Oracle Linked to Egyptian Mysticism. The Sibyl of Cumae, a prophetess in Roman mythology, was believed to be influenced by Egyptian mystical traditions.

greek_influence.name: Seis
greek_influence.description: Temple of Neith, Egypt. Plato wrote that Egyptian priests in Sais told Solon the story of Atlantis.

greek_influence.name: Richat Structure
greek_influence.description: Speculated as Plato’s Atlantis due to its circular structure and location.

greek_influence.name: Herakleion & Thonis
greek_influence.description: Ancient Egyptian port city, sunken in the Mediterranean, where Greek and Egyptian cultures met.

greek_influence.name: Tartessos
greek_influence.description: Ancient Iberian Civilization. A lost civilization mentioned by the Greeks, sometimes linked to Atlantis.

greek_influence.name: Jebel Musa
greek_influence.description: Pillar of Hercules, Morocco. Ancient writers believed Atlantis lay beyond these pillars, linking them to Plato’s legend.

greek_influence.name: Rock of Gibraltar
greek_influence.description: The Myth of Hercules & the Pillars of Hercules. In Greek mythology, Hercules separated these two mountains to create the Strait of Gibraltar.

greek_influence.name: Atlas Mountains
greek_influence.description: In Greek mythology, Atlas was condemned to hold up the sky and was linked to a great land named Atlantis. The mountains were named after him, and some theories suggest Atlantis was located nearby.

greek_influence.name: Phoenician Lixus, Morocco
greek_influence.description: Possible Atlantis location.

greek_influence.name: Madeira
greek_influence.description: Some historians believe Greek myths of western lands were inspired by Egyptian & Phoenician maps.
